name: Lie group
rephrased: A Lie group is a mathematical structure that combines the properties of a group (a set with an associative operation, identity, and inverses) with those of a geometric surface (a manifold, which looks locally like flat space). This means you can perform smooth, continuous operations like multiplication and inversion on the group elements.
implication_form: If a mathematical object is a group and also a smooth manifold, then it is a Lie group.
explained: A Lie group is a mathematical structure that combines the algebraic concepts of a group with the geometric concepts of a differentiable manifold. Formally, it is a finite-dimensional real smooth manifold G (a Hausdorff space that is locally Euclidean) equipped with a group structure (a binary operation ·, identity element e, and inversion map ·↦¹⁻¹) such that the multiplication map (g,h)↦g·h: G×G→G and the inversion map g↦g⁻¹: G→G are both smooth (infinitely differentiable) maps. This smooth structure makes Lie groups fundamental objects in the study of continuous symmetries.
